Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The temple holds a routine evening chant.
Story: The clock on my monitor blinked 5:55 p.m., and my shift as a telemarketer was supposed to end at six sharp. My headset pressed against my ears, the hum of the call center blending with the low anxiety in my chest. The automated compliance system tracked every second, and I knew if I logged off even a minute early, I’d get flagged—again. But tonight was the temple’s evening chant, a ritual I’d promised myself never to miss. The community would be gathering, incense curling through the air, voices rising in unison. As a Buddhist, I was expected to be present, to help set up cushions, to join the circle and let go of worldly concerns. Yet here I was, tethered to my desk, the demands of my job pulling me one way, my spiritual commitments pulling me another. My supervisor’s warning from last week echoed in my mind, but so did the gentle reminder from my teacher: “Practice is not just for when it’s easy.” My hand hovered over the log-off button, heart pounding, caught between the rigid schedule of my work and the quiet call of the temple bell.
